      10             : /*
      11             : 
      12             : interpret.c -- IL interpreter for constexpr functions
      13             : 
      14             : */
      15             : 
      16             : /* Header files common to all files. */
      17             : #include "fe_common.h"
      18             : 
      19             : #ifdef PCH_PRAGMA_GUARD
      20             : /* Mark the end of the sequence of headers subject to precompiled header
      21             :    processing. */
      22             : #pragma hdrstop
      23             : #endif /* ifdef PCH_PRAGMA_GUARD */
      24             : 
      25             : #include "interpret.h"
      26             : 
      27             : #include "class_decl.h"
      28             : 
      29             : #include "exprutil.h"
      30             : 
      31             : #include "folding.h"
      32             : 
      33             : #if DO_IL_LOWERING
      34             : #include "lower_il.h"
      35             : #endif /* DO_IL_LOWERING */
      36             : 
      37             : #include "templates.h"
      38             : 
      39             : /*
      40             : This file implements an interpreter for a subset of the unlowered IL produced
      41             : by the C++ front end.  Specifically, the subset corresponds to the constructs
      42             : allowed in a constant expression in C++14.
      43             : 
      44             : 
      45             : The Interpreter
      46             : ---------------
      47             : The interpreter itself traverses the IL in typical "recursive descent" fashion.
      48             : The principal entry points are interpret_expr, interpret_constexpr_call,
      49             : interpret_dynamic_init, and interpret_constexpr_ctor.  These set up an
      50             : "interpreter state" that is carried through the interpretation process (this
      51             : state includes local allocations and mappings, the call stack, diagnostic
      52             : records, etc.).
      53             : 
      54             : An interpreter invocation can end for one of three reasons:
      55             :   (1) the call is completed with a valid result (normal case),
      56             :   (2) interpretation runs into an invalid operation (e.g., an attempt to
      57             :       read an uninitialized value), or
      58             :   (3) the cost of the interpretation is too high.
      59             : 
      60             : Regarding the latter reason, the interpreter tracks the sum of twice the number
      61             : of calls and the number of loop-back branches.  When that number reaches a
      62             : certain large value, the interpretation is deemed too expensive.  Deeply nested
      63             : recursion is also limited.
      64             : 
      65             : 
      66             : Storage
      67             : -------
      68             : The interpreter manages several pools of storage:
      69             :   (1) automatic variables and temporaries;
      70             :   (2) static data storage;
      71             :   (3) permanent data associated with declarative entities
      72             :       (e.g., field offsets); and
      73             :   (4) maps (see below).
      74             : 
      75             : The first kind of storage is allocated/deallocated in strict last-in/first-out
      76             : (LIFO) manner, and so is efficiently implemented using a storage stack.  It is
      77             : implemented here through a structure of type a_storage_stack_state, which
      78             : maintains a linked list of large blocks from which small chunks are allocated
      79             : /deallocated (adding a large block whenever the last added one is full).  To
      80             : avoid excessive waste, larger chunks (which should be uncommon) are not
      81             : allocated from the large blocks, but separately (through the front end's
      82             : normal memory allocator).
      83             : 
      84             : Almost every variable and temporary triggers an allocation performed through
      85             : the macro alloc_stack_bytes.  Deallocation, on the other hand, is batched
      86             : "per scope" (for variables) or "per full expression" (for temporaries).  The
      87             : macros save_storage_stack and restore_storage_stack support this.
      88             : 
      89             : A wrinkle in this mechanism are temporaries whose lifetime is extended because
      90             : they are bound to a reference.  This is handled by starting a new storage stack
      91             : when the reference is encountered while recording the original stack in the
      92             : interpreter state (see an_interpreter_state::extension_state).  When the
      93             : temporary to be bound is encountered, it is allocated in the original stack,
      94             : which ensures it will live as long as the reference.
      95             : 
      96             : The second kind of storage (static data) is similar to the first in that it is
      97             : associated with a specific interpreter invocation, but it persists until the
      98             : end of that invocation.  This is used, e.g., for string literal storage.  It
      99             : also uses the a_storage_stack_state structure, but is only initialized if it
     100             : is actually needed during interpretation (see the fields static_storage_ready
     101             : and static_storage in an_interpreter_state).  See also alloc_static_bytes.
     102             : 
     103             : The third kind of storage persists across interpreter invocations.  It also
     104             : uses a storage stack (see the static variable persistent_data), although the
     105             : ability to efficiently deallocate is not exploited in that case.  The macro
     106             : alloc_bytes can be used for these allocations.
     107             : 
     108             : The fourth kind of storage is that managed by maps (see below).  This uses a
     109             : separate allocation strategy.
     110             : 
     111             : 
     112             : Mappings
     113             : --------
     114             : The interpreter makes use of an efficient hash table data structure that maps
     115             : pointers (the "key") to either pointers or byte counts (the "value").  The
     116             : type describing such a "map" is a_data_map.  A new (key, value) pair can be
     117             : added with macro map_ptr or map_byte_count.  A mapping can then be retrieved
     118             : with get_mapped_ptr or get_mapped_byte_count.  A recorded mapping for a given
     119             : key can be revoked with unmap_ptr.  (Most of the time, the key is a pointer
     120             : into IL.)
     121             : 
     122             : The interpreter state includes a data map for automatic variables and
     123             : temporaries; convenience macros map_stack_bytes, unmap_stack_bytes, and
     124             : get_stack_bytes can be used to manage that data map.  For example, if a
     125             : stmk_init statement entry is interpreted, storage is allocated for the variable
     126             : and the pointer to the associated a_variable entry is mapped to that storage
     127             : address.
     128             : 
     129             : This map tracking automatic variables and temporaries is also used to map
     130             : run-time namespace-scope variables to a_constant entries representing their
     131             : address (this is done by mapping a_variable::initializer).
     132             : 
     133             : If a pointer to be mapped may already be in a map, use map_or_replace_ptr
     134             : (or replace_mapped_ptr) instead of map_ptr.  It will replace the mapping
     135             : recorded in the data map.
     136             : 
     137             : Besides the data map associated with an interpreter state, another map is kept
     138             : that persists across interpreter invocations (static variable persistent_map).
     139             : This map, e.g., holds data layout information associated with types and fields
     140             : (the data layout for the interpreter is different from that for the target
     141             : architecture).
     142             : 
     143             : 
     144             : Object Layout
     145             : -------------
     146             : A complete object (i.e., an object that is not a subobject of another object)
     147             : stored in a storage stack consists of a "prefix" followed by the representation
     148             : of the value of that object.  The prefix has the following components in order:
     149             : 
     150             :   init_bits[n]
     151             :   init_bits[n-1]
     152             :   ...
     153             :   init_bits[0]
     154             :   init_flag
     155             :   type_ptr
     156             :   (data representation starts here)
     157             : 
     158             : Given a data pointer, traversing the prefix backwards provides the type of the
     159             : complete object (type_ptr), a byte (init_flag) that is zero until the object
     160             : is fully initialized, and, for class and array objects, bit sets indicating
     161             : whether a given offset in the data representation has been initialized.  Note
     162             : that only one bit is set per scalar entity.  For example, if integers are
     163             : represented using eight bytes and the leading entry of an array is initialized,
     164             : then bit 0 of init_bits[0] will be set, but bits 1 through 7 will remain
     165             : unchanged even though their corresponding bytes have valid values.
     166             : 
     167             : The representation of variables (including parameters) also has a "postfix"
     168             : block that includes (a) an allocation sequence number that describes its
     169             : lifetime and (b) a pointer to any storage previously associated with that
     170             : variable (for recursive calls).
     171             : 
     172             : Integer and floating-point values are stored using their IL representations 
     173             : (i.e., an_integer_value and an_internal_float_value).  Bit fields occupy a
     174             : whole integer value, but every "store" to a bit field is appropriately trimmed.
     175             : 
     176             : Class type objects and subobjects start with an IL pointer (described below),
     177             : followed by storage for the fields, storage for nonvirtual direct base classes,
     178             : and finally storage for virtual base classes (all in declaration order).
     179             : A derived-to-base class cast therefore always corresponds to a positive offset
     180             : of the "this" pointer, whereas a base-to-derived class cast involves negative
     181             : offset.
     182             : 
     183             : For objects of union type, the leading pointer points to the a_field
     184             : corresponding to the "active field" (attempting to read a non-active field
     185             : results in interpretation failure).  
     186             : 
     187             : The storage of a non-union class type ("class" or "struct") starts with a
     188             : pointer to an IL entry for the corresponding direct base class entry of the
     189             : next-derived subobject, or NULL for the most-derived subobject.  This is used
     190             : to catch invalid base-to-derived casts (or certain invalid accesses to a
     191             : derived-object member through a pointer-to-member value).
     192             : 
     193             : Pointers (and references, lvalues, and xvalues) are represented with type
     194             : a_constexpr_address.  Often, all that is needed is a pointer into interpreter
     195             : storage.  However, there are many variations:
     196             : 
     197             :   - pointers to array elements, for which bounds must be maintained;
     198             :   - pointers to items in unions, for which the access path (see type
     199             :     a_variant_path_entry) must be maintained so that it can be checked
     200             :     against active fields when the address is read from;
     201             :   - pointers to functions or entities not known at compile time;
     202             :   - etc.
     203             : 
     204             : In addition, when comparing pointers using, e.g., the '<' operator, the
     205             : interpreter must ensure that the pointers point to the same complete
     206             : object.  a_constexpr_address therefore includes a pointer to the complete
     207             : object it points to (assuming it is a pointer to interpreter storage).
     208             : 
     209             : When reading through a_constexpr_address, the front end must ensure that the
     210             : storage it points to is still valid.  To this end, every variable and temporary
     211             : allocated in the interpreter has an associated allocation sequence number, and
     212             : that number is recorded when an address for that entity is formed (for a
     213             : pointer, lvalue, or xvalue).  When an allocation sequence number is created, it
     214             : is also recorded in a hash table described by a_live_set (see field live_set in
     215             : an_interpreter_state); it is removed when the associated storage is reclaimed.
     216             : Every read through a_constexpr_address therefore just has to check that the
     217             : recorded allocation sequence number is still in the live table (if not,
     218             : interpretation fails).
     219             : 
     220             : The a_constexpr_address representation is sufficient to re-create the complete
     221             : "symbolic path" needed to obtain it from a complete object.  E.g., if the
     222             : address is in an object x, perhaps an expression like "x.y[3].z" is needed to
     223             : produce that address: The ".y[3].z" path can be reconstructed and this may be
     224             : needed when comparing pointers or when translating interpreter addresses back
     225             : to a_constant/ck_address entries.
     226             : 
     227             : Pointer-to-member values are represented by the a_constexpr_ptr_to_mem type.
     228             : 
     229             : 
     230             : Local Macro Names
     231             : -----------------
     232             : The implementation of the interpreter makes liberal use of macros.  In a few
     233             : cases, the macros are specific to a local function context and they make use
     234             : of local variables not passed through parameters.  Such local macros are named
     235             : with a capitalized leading word (a visual reminder that their effect is broader
     236             : than may seem at first).  See, e.g., SET_result_val_from_operand_address in
     237             : do_constexpr_expression.
     238             : */
     239             : 
     240             : typedef unsigned int a_byte_count;
     241             : 
     242             : typedef unsigned int an_alloc_seq_number;
     243             :                         /* An integral type used to number allocations and
     244             :                            track whether an allocation is still "live" (via
     245             :                            a_live_set -- see below).  A zero value corresponds
     246             :                            to static storage. */
     247             : 
     248             : /*
     249             : Macro to set the flag indicating that interpretation has failed.  In DEBUG
     250             : configurations, a breakpoint on constexpr_fail_intercept is useful to find
     251             : where interpretation fails. 
     252             : */
     253             : #if DEBUG && !defined(_lint)
     254             : #define do_constexpr_fail(flag) (constexpr_fail_intercept(), ((flag) = FALSE))
     255             : 
     256       23857 : static void constexpr_fail_intercept(void)
     257             : /*
     258             : This function exists solely to intercept interpretation failure in a debugger.
     259             : */
     260             : {
     261       23857 : }  /* constexpr_fail_intercept */
     262             : 
     263             : #else /* !(DEBUG  && !defined(_lint)) */
     264             : #define do_constexpr_fail(flag) ((flag) = FALSE)
     265             : #endif /* DEBUG && !defined(_lint) */
     266             : 
     267             : 
     268             : /*
     269             : Macro defining the size of large blocks allocated for a storage stack.  These
     270             : large blocks are then parceled out in smaller chunks as requested through the
     271             : macro alloc_bytes.  If an alloc_bytes request is too large, however, the
     272             : storage is not carved from the large blocks; instead, it is allocated from
     273             : general memory.
     274             : */
     275             : #define CONSTEXPR_STACK_BLOCK_SIZE (1<<16)
     276             : 
     277             : /*
     278             : Macro defining the largest chunk size to be carved from storage stack blocks
     279             : (see CONSTEXPR_STACK_BLOCK_SIZE above).  Invocations of alloc_bytes that
     280             : request larger chunks are handled in terms of individual calls to alloc_general
     281             : (and are freed by a call to free_general).
     282             : */
     283             : #define CONSTEXPR_STACK_ALLOC_LIMIT (1<<10)
     284             : 
     285             : /*
     286             : Structure describing a state of the allocation stack.  States can be saved to
     287             : be restored later (effectively "popping" the allocation stack).
     288             : */
     289             : typedef struct a_storage_stack_state {
     290             :   a_byte        *top;
     291             :                         /* A pointer to the next byte available for allocation
     292             :                            in the interpreter's storage stack. */
     293             :   a_byte        *curr_block;
     294             :                         /* The current block in the interpreter's storage
     295             :                            stack.  The start of a block has (in order): the
     296             :                            previous block, the next block, and the top of the
     297             :                            stack when this block last became non-current. */
     298             :   a_byte        *large_blocks;
     299             :                         /* A pointer to the last allocated large block (or NULL
     300             :                            if there is none). */
     301             :   an_alloc_seq_number
     302             :                 alloc_seq_number;
     303             :                         /* A sequence number used to detect leaks. */
     304             : } a_storage_stack_state;
     305             : 
     306             : 
     307             : typedef struct a_large_block_header {
     308             :   a_byte        *prev_large_block;
     309             :                         /* Pointer to the previously allocated large block (or
     310             :                            NULL if none). */
     311             :   a_byte_count  block_size;
     312             :                         /* Size of this block. */
     313             :   an_alloc_seq_number
     314             :                 alloc_seq_number;
     315             :                         /* A sequence number used to manage deallocation. */
     316             : } a_large_block_header;
     317             : 
     318             : 
     319             : static a_storage_stack_state
     320             :                 persistent_data;
     321             :                         /* Data that persists across interpreter invocations.
     322             :                            In particular, data describing the layout of data
     323             :                            in the interpreter. */
     324             : 
     325             : static unsigned long count_ones(unsigned long n)
     326             : /*
     327             : Return the number of trailing "ones" in the binary representation of n.
     328             : */
     329             : {
     330             :   unsigned long r = 0;
     331             : 
     332             :   while (n != 0) {
     333             :     if (n&1) {
     334             :       ++r;
     335             :     }  /* if */
     336             :     n >>= 1;
     337             :   }  /* while */
     338             :   return r;
     339             : }  /* count_ones */
     340             : 
     341             : /*
     342             : Type to use to index into a data map.
     343             : */
     344             : typedef unsigned int a_map_index;
     345             : 
     346             : 
     347             : /*
     348             : Union for the kinds of values that a data map maps to.
     349             : */
     350             : typedef union a_mapped_value {
     351             :   a_byte        *ptr;
     352             :                         /* A pointer. */
     353             :   a_byte_count
     354             :                 byte_count;
     355             :                         /* A byte count. */
     356             : } a_mapped_value;
     357             : 
     358             : 
     359             : /*
     360             : Structure mapping pointers in the IL to associated data in the interpreter.
     361             : (E.g., to map a variable to its associated storage, or a type to its associated
     362             : layout data.)
     363             : */
     364             : typedef struct a_data_map_entry {
     365             :   a_byte        *ptr;
     366             :                         /* A pointer mapped by this entry.  (A "key" in the
     367             :                            hash table.) */
     368             :   a_mapped_value
     369             :                 data;
     370             :                         /* A value associated with ptr. */
     371             : } a_data_map_entry;
     372             : 
     373             : 
     374             : /*
     375             : Structure describing a data map.  (Implemented has a hash table with linear
     376             : probing.)
     377             : */
     378             : typedef struct a_data_map {
     379             :   a_data_map_entry
     380             :                 *table;
     381             :                         /* Hash table mapping pointers into the IL onto
     382             :                            associated data. */
     383             :   a_map_index
     384             :                 hash_mask;
     385             :                         /* The mask to apply to the hash value before indexing
     386             :                            in the table.  This mask is increased as the table
     387             :                            grows. */
     388             :   a_map_index
     389             :                 n_elements;
     390             :                         /* The number of elements stored in the table. */
     391             : } a_data_map;
     392             : 
     393             : 
     394             : static a_data_map
     395             :                 persistent_map;
     396             :                         /* Map that persists across interpreter invocations.
     397             :                            In particular, its entries describe the layout of
     398             :                            data in the interpreter. */
     399             : 
     400             : #define MAX_WIDTH_REUSABLE_TABLE 10
     401             : static a_data_map_entry
     402             :                 *free_map_tables[MAX_WIDTH_REUSABLE_TABLE+1];
     403             :                         /* A array of pointers to map tables available for
     404             :                            reuse.  free_map_table[n] points to a list of tables
     405             :                            allocated for 1<<n entries.  Larger tables use
     406             :                            alloc_general and free_general. */
     407             : 
     408             : 
     409       10309 : static void init_data_map(a_data_map    *map,
     410             :                           unsigned int  mask_width)
     411             : /*
     412             : Initialize the given data map.
     413             : */

     415       10309 :   unsigned      n_slots = (1<<mask_width);

     417             :

     419           0 :     map->table = (a_data_map_entry*)alloc_general(size);
     420       10309 :   } else if (free_map_tables[mask_width] != NULL) {

     423       10263 :                           (a_data_map_entry*)free_map_tables[mask_width]->ptr;

     425          46 :     map->table = (a_data_map_entry*)alloc_fe(size);
     426             :   }  /* if */
     427       10309 :   memzero((char*)map->table, size_t_arg(size));
     428       10309 :   map->hash_mask = n_slots-1;

     430       10309 : }  /* init_data_map */
     431             : 
     432             : 
     433             : static void release_data_map_table(a_data_map  *map)
     434             : /*
     435             : Release the storage for the given map's table.
     436             : */

     438             :   a_map_index       mask = map->hash_mask;
     439             :   a_map_index       n_slots = mask+1;
     440             :   a_byte_count      size = n_slots*sizeof(a_data_map_entry);
     441             :   unsigned long     mask_width = count_ones(mask);

     444             :     free_general(map->table, size);
     445             :   } else {
     446             :     map->table[0].ptr = (a_byte*)free_map_tables[mask_width];
     447             :     free_map_tables[mask_width] = map->table;
     448             :   }  /* if */
     449             : }  /* release_data_map_table */
     450             : 
     451             : 
     452             : /*
     453             : Structure describing a call context.
     454             : */
     455             : typedef struct a_call_frame *a_call_frame_ptr;
     456             : typedef struct a_call_frame {
     457             :   a_call_frame_ptr
     458             :                 parent;
     459             :                         /* The frame in which this frame was created. */
     460             :   a_routine_ptr routine;

     468             :   a_byte        *complete_object;

     473             :   a_bit_field   loop_break_active:1;

     483             : 
     484             : 
     485             : 
     486             : /*
     487             : Type to use to index into a live set.
     488             : */
     489             : typedef unsigned int a_live_set_index;
     490             : 
     491             : 
     492             : /*
     493             : A hash table maintaining a set of "live" allocation sequence numbers (i.e., the
     494             : sequence numbers of allocations that have not been deallocated yet).  Unlike
     495             : most hash tables this table only holds "keys", not associated "values".
     496             : */
     497             : typedef struct a_live_set {
     498             :   an_alloc_seq_number
     499             :                 *table;
     500             :                         /* The hash table proper. */
     501             :   a_live_set_index
     502             :                 hash_mask;
     503             :                         /* The mask to apply to the hash value before indexing
     504             :                            in the table.  This mask is increased as the table
     505             :                            grows. */
     506             :   a_live_set_index
     507             :                 n_elements;
     508             :                         /* The number of elements stored in the table. */
     509             : } a_live_set;
     510             : 
     511             : static an_alloc_seq_number
     512             :                 *free_live_set_tables[MAX_WIDTH_REUSABLE_TABLE+1];
     513             :                         /* A array of pointers to live set tables available for
     514             :                            reuse.  free_live_set_table[n] points to a list of
     515             :                            tables allocated for 1<<n entries.  Larger tables
     516             :                            use alloc_general and free_general.*/
     517             : 
     518             : 
     519       10291 : static void init_live_set(a_live_set  *set)
     520             : /*
     521             : Initialize the given live set.
     522             : */
     523             : {
     524       10291 :   unsigned      mask_width = 3, n_slots = (1<<mask_width);
     525       10291 :   a_byte_count  size = n_slots*sizeof(an_alloc_seq_number);
     526             : 
     527       10291 :   if (free_live_set_tables[mask_width] != NULL) {
     528       10263 :     set->table = free_live_set_tables[mask_width];
     529       10263 :     free_live_set_tables[mask_width] =
     530       10263 :                      *(an_alloc_seq_number**)free_live_set_tables[mask_width];
     531             :   } else {
     532          28 :     set->table = (an_alloc_seq_number*)alloc_fe(size);
     533             :   }  /* if */
     534       10291 :   memzero((char*)set->table, size_t_arg(size));
     535       10291 :   set->hash_mask = n_slots-1;
     536       10291 :   set->n_elements = 0;
     537       10291 : }  /* init_live_set */
     538             : 
     539             : 
     540             : static void release_live_set_table(a_live_set  *set)
     541             : /*
     542             : Release the storage for the given set's table.
     543             : */
     544             : {
     545             :   a_live_set_index  mask = set->hash_mask;
     546             :   a_live_set_index  n_slots = mask+1;
     547             :   a_byte_count      size = n_slots*sizeof(an_alloc_seq_number);
     548             :   unsigned long     mask_width = count_ones(mask);
     549             : 
     550             :   if (mask_width > MAX_WIDTH_REUSABLE_TABLE) {
     551             :     free_general(set->table, size);
     552             :   } else {
     553             :     *(an_alloc_seq_number**)set->table = free_live_set_tables[mask_width];
     554             :     free_live_set_tables[mask_width] = set->table;
     555             :   }  /* if */
     556             : }  /* release_live_set_table */
     557             : 
     558             : 
     559             : #define hash_alloc_seq_number(seq)                                           \
     560             :   (seq)
     561             : 
     562             : 
     563             : static void expand_live_set(a_live_set  *set)
     564             : /*
     565             : Double the number of entries in the given set.  This requires rehashing.
     566             : */
     567             : {
     568             :   an_alloc_seq_number  *new_table, *old_table = set->table;
     569             :   a_live_set_index     mask = set->hash_mask;
     570             :   a_live_set_index     k, n_slots = mask+1;
     571             :   a_byte_count         old_size = n_slots*sizeof(an_alloc_seq_number);
     572             :   a_byte_count         new_size = 2*old_size;
     573             :   unsigned long        new_width = count_ones(mask)+1, old_width;
     574             : 
     575             :   if (new_width > MAX_WIDTH_REUSABLE_TABLE) {
     576             :     new_table = (an_alloc_seq_number*)alloc_general(new_size);
     577             :   } else if (free_live_set_tables[new_width] != NULL) {
     578             :     new_table = free_live_set_tables[new_width];
     579             :     free_live_set_tables[new_width] =
     580             :                       *(an_alloc_seq_number**)free_live_set_tables[new_width];
     581             :   } else {
     582             :     new_table = (an_alloc_seq_number*)alloc_fe(new_size);
     583             :   }  /* if */
     584             :   memzero((char*)new_table, size_t_arg(new_size));
     585             :   mask = mask*2+1;
     586             :   for (k = 0; k<n_slots; ++k) {
     587             :     an_alloc_seq_number  seq = old_table[k];
     588             :     if (seq != 0) {
     589             :       a_live_set_index  idx = hash_alloc_seq_number(seq) & mask;
     590             :       while (new_table[idx] != 0) {
     591             :         idx = (idx+1) & mask;
     592             :       }  /* while */
     593             :       new_table[idx] = old_table[k];
     594             :     }  /* if */
     595             :   }  /* for */
     596             :   set->table = new_table;
     597             :   set->hash_mask = mask;
     598             :   old_width = new_width-1;
     599             :   if (old_width > MAX_WIDTH_REUSABLE_TABLE) {
     600             :     free_general(old_table, old_size);
     601             :   } else {
     602             :     *(an_alloc_seq_number**)old_table = free_live_set_tables[old_width];
     603             :     free_live_set_tables[old_width] = old_table;
     604             :   }  /* if */
     605             : }  /* expand_live_set */
     606             : 
     607             : 
     608             : /*
     609             : Macro to add an allocation sequence number to a live set.  (It may not be in
     610             : the set already.)
     611             : */
     612             : #define add_to_live_set(set, alloc_seq)                                      \
     613             : {                                                                            \
     614             :   uintptr_t            hash = hash_alloc_seq_number(alloc_seq);              \
     615             :   a_live_set_index     mask = (set)->hash_mask;                              \
     616             :   a_live_set_index     idx = hash & mask;                                    \
     617             :   an_alloc_seq_number  *table = (set)->table;                                \
     618             :   if (table[idx] == 0) {                                                     \
     619             :     table[idx] = (alloc_seq);                                                \
     620             :   } else {                                                                   \
     621             :     set_colliding_seq(set, alloc_seq, idx);                                  \
     622             :   }  /* if */                                                                \
     623             :   (set)->n_elements += 1;                                                    \
     624             :   if ((set)->n_elements*2 > mask) {                                          \
     625             :     expand_live_set(set);                                                    \
     626             :   }  /* if */                                                                \
     627             : }
     628             : 
     629             : 
     630           0 : static void set_colliding_seq(a_live_set           *set,
     631             :                               an_alloc_seq_number  seq,
     632             :                               a_live_set_index     idx)
     633             : /*
     634             : The given allocation sequence number collides with an existing entry in the
     635             : given set.  Move the existing entry to the next available spot and place seq
     636             : at idx.
     637             : */
     638             : {
     639           0 :   a_live_set_index     mask = set->hash_mask;
     640           0 :   an_alloc_seq_number  *table = set->table;
     641           0 :   an_alloc_seq_number  saved_seq;
     642             : 
     643             :   /* Place the new number at idx, and move the existing entry to the next
     644             :      available spot. */
     645           0 :   saved_seq = table[idx];
     646           0 :   table[idx] = seq;
     647           0 :   for (;;) {
     648           0 :     idx = (idx+1) & mask;
     649           0 :     if (table[idx] == 0) {
     650           0 :       table[idx] = saved_seq;
     651           0 :       break;
     652             :     }  /* if */
     653             :   }  /* for */
     654           0 : }  /* set_colliding_seq */
     655             : 
     656             : 
     657             : #define remove_from_live_set(set, alloc_seq)                                 \
     658             : {                                                                            \
     659             :   uintptr_t            hash = hash_alloc_seq_number(alloc_seq);              \
     660             :   a_live_set_index     mask = (set)->hash_mask;                              \
     661             :   a_live_set_index     idx = hash & mask;                                    \
     662             :   an_alloc_seq_number  *table = (set)->table;                                \
     663             :   /* Find the item to delete (we're assuming it exists). */                  \
     664             :   while (table[idx] != alloc_seq) {                                          \
     665             :     idx = (idx+1) & mask;                                                    \
     666             :   }  /* while */                                                             \
     667             :   table[idx] = 0;                                                            \
     668             :   /* If the next slot is empty, we're done.  Otherwise, we may have to */    \
     669             :   /* move another element into the emptied slot. */                          \
     670             :   if (table[(idx+1) & mask] != 0) {                                          \
     671             :     check_deleted_live_set_slot(set, idx);                                   \
     672             :   }  /* if */                                                                \
     673             :   (set)->n_elements -= 1;                                                    \
     674             : }
     675             : 
     676             : 
     677             : static void check_deleted_live_set_slot(a_live_set        *set,
     678             :                                         a_live_set_index  idx0)
     679             : /*
     680             : Slot idx has been cleared in the given set (i.e., set->table[idx].ptr has been
     681             : set to zero).  The next slot is not empty.  There may therefore exist entries
     682             : that are associated with that slot (i.e., have the same hash index).  This
     683             : function makes sure that such entries can be found, by moving up entries as
     684             : needed.
     685             : 
     686             : This corresponds to Algorithm R in section 6.4 of volume 3 of Donald E. Knuth's
     687             : "The Art of Computer Programming" (Sorting and Searching -- Second Edition),
     688             : with the assumption that step R1 has already been performed (idx0 is "j") and
     689             : we know that the subsequent slot is not empty.
     690             : */
     691             : {
     692             :   an_alloc_seq_number  *table = set->table;
     693             :   a_live_set_index     mask = set->hash_mask;
     694             :   a_live_set_index     idx, ridx;
     695             :   an_alloc_seq_number  rseq;
     696             :   
     697             :   idx = (idx0+1) & mask;
     698             :   rseq = table[idx];
     699             :   for (;;) {
     700             :     for (;;) {
     701             :       ridx = hash_alloc_seq_number(rseq) & mask;
     702             :       /* See if we can move the entry at idx to idx0.  ridx is its "ideal"
     703             :          slot: the place from where probing will start.  So we cannot move it
     704             :          ahead of there.  I.e., if idx0 lies outside [ridx, idx-1] (considering
     705             :          "wrap-around"), do not move the entry and try the next entry
     706             :          instead. */
     707             :       if ((ridx <= idx0 && idx0 < idx) ||
     708             :           (idx0 >= ridx && idx < ridx) ||
     709             :           (idx0 < idx && idx < ridx)) {
     710             :         /* idx0 is in [ridx, idx-1]: Move the entry. */
     711             :         break;
     712             :       } else {
     713             :         idx = (idx+1) & mask;
     714             :         rseq = table[idx];
     715             :         if (rseq == 0) goto done;
     716             :       }  /* if */
     717             :     }  /* for */
     718             :     table[idx0] = table[idx];
     719             :     table[idx] = 0;
     720             :     idx0 = idx;
     721             :     idx = (idx0+1) & mask;
     722             :     rseq = table[idx];
     723             :     if (rseq == 0) goto done;
     724             :   }  /* for */
     725             : done:;
     726             : }  /* check_deleted_live_set_slot */
     727             : 
     728             : 
     729             : /*
     730             : Return TRUE if the given allocation sequence number is in the given live set.
     731             : This macro is written with the assumption that in the vast majority of cases
     732             : the sequence number is present and it needs no probing to be found.
     733             : */
     734             : #define in_live_set(set, seq)                                                \
     735             :   ((set)->table[hash_alloc_seq_number(seq) & (set)->hash_mask] == seq ?      \
     736             :      TRUE : f_in_live_set(set, seq))
     737             : 
     738             : 
     739           0 : static a_boolean f_in_live_set(a_live_set           *set,
     740             :                                an_alloc_seq_number  seq)
     741             : /*
     742             : Return TRUE if the given allocation sequence number is in the given live set.
     743             : Return FALSE otherwise.  This is normally always called through the macro
     744             : in_live_set.
     745             : */
     746             : {
     747           0 :   a_boolean  result;
     748             : 
     749           0 :   if (seq == 0) {
     750             :     /* Sequence number zero (static storage) is always "live". */
     751             :     result = TRUE;
     752             :   } else {
     753           0 :     a_live_set_index     mask = set->hash_mask;
     754             :     a_live_set_index     idx = hash_alloc_seq_number(seq) & mask;
     755           0 :     an_alloc_seq_number  *table = set->table;
     756           0 :     for (;;) {
     757           0 :       an_alloc_seq_number  tseq = table[idx];
     758           0 :       if (tseq == seq) {
     759             :         result = TRUE;
     760             :         break;
     761           0 :       } else if (tseq == 0) {
     762             :         result = FALSE;
     763             :         break;
     764             :       }  /* if */
     765           0 :       idx = (idx+1) & mask;
     766             :     }  /* for */
     767             :   }  /* if */
     768           0 :   return result;
     769             : }  /* f_in_live_set */
     770             : 
     771             :

     788             : /*
     789             : Structure maintaining data about the IL interpreter across a complete
     790             : interpretation of a constexpr function and its callees.
     791             : */
     792             : typedef struct an_interpreter_state {
     793             :   a_data_map
     794             :                 map;
     795             :                         /* Hash table mapping pointers into the IL onto
     796             :                            associated data. */
     797             :   a_storage_stack_state
     798             :                 storage_stack;
     799             :                         /* The current state of the storage stack. */
     800             :   a_live_set
     801             :                 live_set;
     802             :                         /* The set of allocation sequence numbers that are
     803             :                            still "live". */
     804             :   a_call_frame_ptr
     805             :                 curr_call_frame;

     807             :   a_storage_stack_state
     808             :                 *extension_state;
     809             :                         /* Pointer to the storage stack state from which a
     810             :                            temporary with extended lifetime should be
     811             :                            allocated. */

     813             :                 constants;
     814             :                         /* A list of local constants allocated for the
     815             :                            interpreter (to be released when interpretation is
     816             :                            done). */
     817             :   a_diag_list
     818             :                 diag_list;

     820             :                            explaining why interpretation failed to produce a
     821             :                            constant result).  These diagnostics are not
     822             :                            necessarily emitted (we may be in a SFINAE context,
     823             :                            or in an initialization context that permits both
     824             :                            constant and non-constant initializers). */

     826             :                 position;
     827             :                         /* The position of the expression where interpretation
     828             :                            starts. */

     831             :                            number of calls and loop-back branches. */

     838             :                 static_storage_ready:1;

     840             :   a_bit_field
     841             :                 side_effects_disabled:1;

     843             :                            increments/decrements) are disabled.  Any such side-
     844             :                            effects cause interpretation failure.  Used for

     846             :                            __builtin_constant_p (a GCC extension). */
     847             :   a_bit_field

     855             :                            entry was encountered in the IL. */
     856             :   a_bit_field

     872             :                            static storage-duration variables.  Initialized
     873             :                            when first needed. */
     874             : } an_interpreter_state;

     876             : 
     877             : #define cost_exceeded(ips)                                                   \
     878             :   (++(ips)->cost > max_cost_constexpr_call)
     879             : 
     880             : 
     881             : static a_byte   *free_stack_blocks;

     885       10337 : static void alloc_constexpr_stack_block(a_storage_stack_state  *sss)
     886             : /*
     887             : Initialize stack storage for the given storage stack.
     888             : */
     889             : {
     890       10337 :   a_byte        *new_block;

     892             : 
     893       10337 :   do_host_alignment(ptr_size);

     895          47 :     new_block = (a_byte*)alloc_fe(CONSTEXPR_STACK_BLOCK_SIZE);
     896             :   } else {

     926             : {

     928             :

     931             :       /* Some blocks are already on the "free blocks" list.  Append those free
     932             :          blocks to those about to be freed. */
     933             :       a_byte        *block, *next_block;

     935        8973 :       do_host_alignment(ptr_size);

     949           0 : void db_live_set(void  *interpreter_state)

     953             : {

     955           0 :   an_alloc_seq_number   num = 1;
     956             : 
     957           0 :   (void)fprintf(f_debug, "live set:");
     958           0 :   while (num <= ips->curr_alloc_seq_number+1) {
     959           0 :     if (in_live_set(&ips->live_set, num)) {

     977           0 : static void add_storage_stack_block(a_storage_stack_state  *sss)
     978             : /*
     979             : Add a block of storage (to parcel out) to the given storage stack.
     980             : */
     981             : {
     982           0 :   a_byte_count  ptr_size = sizeof(a_byte*);
     983           0 :   a_byte        *next_block;
     984             : 
     985           0 :   do_host_alignment(ptr_size);
     986             :   /* Record the current stack top in the bookkeeping section. */
     987           0 :   *(a_byte**)(sss->curr_block+2*ptr_size) = sss->top;
     988           0 :   next_block = *(a_byte**)(sss->curr_block+ptr_size);
     989           0 :   if (next_block == NULL) {
     990             :     /* The current block is the last block: Allocate a new one. */
     991           0 :     alloc_constexpr_stack_block(sss);
     992             :   } else {
     993             :     /* Reuse a previously-allocated block. */
     994           0 :     sss->curr_block = next_block;
     995             :     /* Leave space for the bookkeeping information (three pointers). */
     996           0 :     sss->top = sss->curr_block+3*ptr_size;
     997             :   }  /* if */
     998           0 : }  /* add_storage_stack_block */
     999             : 
    1000             : 
    1001             : /*
    1002             : Macro to allocate bytes in stack storage.  Deallocation is handled by restoring
    1003             : a previously saved stack state.
    1004             : */
    1005             : #define alloc_bytes(sss, n_bytes, storage_ptr)                               \
    1006             :   { if ((n_bytes) > CONSTEXPR_STACK_ALLOC_LIMIT /*lint -e506*/) {            \
    1007             :       /* We'll allocate the bytes in a separate general allocation block. */ \
    1008             :       a_byte        *large_block;                                            \
    1009             :       a_byte_count  hdr_size = sizeof(a_large_block_header), block_size;     \
    1010             :       do_host_alignment(hdr_size);                                           \
    1011             :       block_size = hdr_size+(n_bytes);                                       \
    1012             :       large_block = (a_byte*)alloc_general(block_size);                      \
    1013             :       ((a_large_block_header*)large_block)->prev_large_block =               \
    1014             :                                                         (sss)->large_blocks; \
    1015             :       ((a_large_block_header*)large_block)->block_size = block_size;         \
    1016             :       ((a_large_block_header*)large_block)->alloc_seq_number =               \
    1017             :                                                     (sss)->alloc_seq_number; \
    1018             :       (sss)->large_blocks = large_block;                                     \
    1019             :       (storage_ptr) = large_block+hdr_size;                                  \
    1020             :     } else {                                                                 \
    1021             :       a_byte_count  size = (n_bytes);                                        \
    1022             :       do_host_alignment(size);                                               \
    1023             :       if (size > stack_bytes_left(sss)) {                                    \
    1024             :         add_storage_stack_block(sss);                                        \
    1025             :       }  /* if */                                                            \
    1026             :       (storage_ptr) = (sss)->top;                                            \
    1027             :       (sss)->top += size;                                                    \
    1028             :     }  /* if */                                                              \
    1029             :   }
    1030             : 
    1031             : 
    1032             : /*
    1033             : Convenience macro to allocate bytes in the storage stack of an interpreter
    1034             : state.
    1035             : */
    1036             : #define alloc_stack_bytes(ips, n_bytes, storage_ptr)                         \
    1037             :   alloc_bytes(&(ips)->storage_stack, n_bytes, storage_ptr)
    1038             : 
    1039             : 
    1040             : /*
    1041             : Convenience macro to allocate bytes in the static storage area of an
    1042             : interpreter state.
    1043             : */
    1044             : #define alloc_static_bytes(ips, n_bytes, storage_ptr)                        \
    1045             : {                                                                            \
    1046             :   if (!(ips)->static_storage_ready) {                                        \
    1047             :     /* This is the first time we allocate static storage: Initialize */      \
    1048             :     /* the associated static storage stack. */                               \
    1049             :     alloc_constexpr_stack_block(&(ips)->static_storage);                     \
    1050             :     (ips)->static_storage_ready = TRUE;                                      \
    1051             :     (ips)->static_storage.alloc_seq_number = 0;                              \
    1052             :   }  /* if */                                                                \
    1053             :   alloc_bytes(&(ips)->static_storage, n_bytes, storage_ptr);                 \
    1054             : }
    1055             : 
    1056             : /*
    1057             : Macros to save and restore an allocation stack state.
    1058             : */
    1059             : #define save_storage_stack(ips, state)                                       \
    1060             : {                                                                            \
    1061             :   (state) = (ips)->storage_stack;                                            \
    1062             :   (ips)->storage_stack.alloc_seq_number = ++(ips)->curr_alloc_seq_number;    \
    1063             :   add_to_live_set(&(ips)->live_set, (ips)->curr_alloc_seq_number);           \
    1064             : }
    1065             : 
    1066             : 
    1067             : #define restore_storage_stack(ips, state)                                    \
    1068             : {                                                                            \
    1069             :   a_byte  *curr_large_blocks = (ips)->storage_stack.large_blocks;            \
    1070             :   remove_from_live_set(&(ips)->live_set,                                     \
    1071             :                        (ips)->storage_stack.alloc_seq_number);               \
    1072             :   (ips)->storage_stack = (state);                                            \
    1073             :   if (curr_large_blocks != NULL &&                                           \
    1074             :       curr_large_blocks != (state).large_blocks) {                           \
    1075             :     /* Delete large blocks no longer in the live set. */                     \
    1076             :     do {                                                                     \
    1077             :       a_byte  *large_block = curr_large_blocks;                              \
    1078             :       an_alloc_seq_number  seq = ((a_large_block_header*)large_block)        \
    1079             :                                                          ->alloc_seq_number; \
    1080             :       if (in_live_set(&(ips)->live_set, seq)) break;                         \
    1081             :       curr_large_blocks = ((a_large_block_header*)large_block)               \
    1082             :                                                       ->prev_large_block;    \
    1083             :       free_general(large_block,                                              \
    1084             :                    ((a_large_block_header*)large_block)->block_size);        \
    1085             :     } while (curr_large_blocks != NULL);                                     \
    1086             :     (ips)->storage_stack.large_blocks = curr_large_blocks;                   \
    1087             :   }  /* if */                                                                \
    1088             : }
    1089             : 
    1090             : 
    1091             : #if defined(__GNUC__) && __GNUC__ == 4 && __GNUC_MINOR__ < 5
    1092             : /*
    1093             : Some versions of GCC 4.x issue spurious "uninitialized" diagnostics when the
    1094             : optimizer is enabled (on code where unneeded initialization is undesirable
    1095             : because of performance concerns).
    1096             : */
    1097             : #define init_storage_stack_state_to_silence_GCC(sss)                         \
    1098             :   ((sss).top = (sss).curr_block = (sss).large_blocks = NULL,                 \
    1099             :    (sss).alloc_seq_number = 0)
    1100             : #else /* !defined(__GNUC__) && ... */
    1101             : #define init_storage_stack_state_to_silence_GCC(sss) /* Nothing */
    1102             : #endif /* defined(__GNUC__) && ... */
    1103             : 
    1104             : 
    1105             : /*
    1106             : Convenience macro to extract a host large integer from the integer value at
    1107             : bytes of type tp, which must be a tk_integer type.  The result is left in
    1108             : val.  ovfl is set to TRUE if the value is too large or small for a host
    1109             : large integer.
    1110             : */
    1111             : #define get_int_val_from(bytes, tp, val, ovfl)                                \
    1112             :   conv_integer_value_to_host_large_integer(                                   \
    1113             :                           (an_integer_value *)(bytes),                        \
    1114             :                           int_kind_is_signed[(tp)->variant.integer.int_kind], \
    1115             :                           &(val), &(ovfl))
    1116             : 
    1117             : 
    1118             : /*
    1119             : Macros to push and pop call frames.
    1120             : */
    1121             : #define push_call_frame(ips, p_frame, rp, pos, p_result, p_complete)         \
    1122             :   {                                                                          \
    1123             :     (p_frame)->parent = (ips)->curr_call_frame;                              \
    1124             :     (p_frame)->routine = (rp);                                               \
    1125             :     (p_frame)->position = (pos);                                             \
    1126             :     (p_frame)->result_storage = (p_result);                                  \
    1127             :     (p_frame)->complete_object = (p_complete);                               \
    1128             :     (p_frame)->return_active = FALSE;                                        \
    1129             :     (p_frame)->loop_break_active = FALSE;                                    \
    1130             :     (p_frame)->continue_active = FALSE;                                      \
    1131             :     (p_frame)->switch_break_active = FALSE;                                  \
    1132             :     (ips)->curr_call_frame = (p_frame);                                      \
    1133             :     (ips)->call_seen = TRUE;                                                 \
    1134             :   }
    1135             : 
    1136             : #define pop_call_frame(ips)                                                  \
    1137             :   ((ips)->curr_call_frame = (ips)->curr_call_frame->parent)
    1138             : 
    1139             : 
    1140             : #if HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED == 1
    1141             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 0
    1142             : #else /* HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED > 1 */
    1143             : #if HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED == 2
    1144             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 1
    1145             : #else /* HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED > 2 */
    1146             : #if HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED == 4
    1147             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 2
    1148             : #else /* HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED > 4 */
    1149             : #if HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED == 8
    1150             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 3
    1151             : #else /* HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED > 8 */
    1152             : #if HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED == 16
    1153             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 4
    1154             : #else /* HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED > 16 */
    1155             : #if HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED == 32
    1156             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 5
    1157             : #else /* HOST_ALIGNMENT_REQUIRED > 32 */
    1158             : #define HASH_PTR_SHIFT 6
    1159             : #endif /* == 32 */
    1160             : #endif /* == 16 */
    1161             : #endif /* == 8 */
    1162             : #endif /* == 4 */
    1163             : #endif /* == 2 */
    1164             : #endif /* == 1 */
    1165             : 
    1166             : #define hash_ptr(ptr)                                                        \
    1167             :    ((uintptr_t)ptr >> HASH_PTR_SHIFT)
    1168             : 
    1169             : 
    1170             : /*
    1171             : Macro to retrieve a pointer (dptr) associated with a pointer (iptr) from a
    1172             : given data map.
    1173             : */
    1174             : #define get_mapped_ptr(map, iptr, dptr)                                      \
    1175             : {                                                                            \
    1176             :   uintptr_t         hash = hash_ptr(iptr);                                   \
    1177             :   a_map_index       mask = (map)->hash_mask;                                 \
    1178             :   a_map_index       idx = hash & mask;                                       \
    1179             :   a_data_map_entry  *table = (map)->table;                                   \
    1180             :   for (;;) {                                                                 \
    1181             :     a_byte  *tptr = table[idx].ptr;                                          \
    1182             :     if (tptr == (a_byte*)(iptr)) {                                           \
    1183             :       (dptr) = table[idx].data.ptr;                                          \
    1184             :       break;                                                                 \
    1185             :     } else if (tptr == NULL) {                                               \
    1186             :       (dptr) = NULL;                                                         \
    1187             :       break;                                                                 \
    1188             :     }  /* if */                                                              \
    1189             :     idx = (idx+1) & mask;                                                    \
    1190             :   }  /* for */                                                               \
    1191             : }
    1192             : 
    1193             : 
    1194             : /*
    1195             : Macro to retrieve a byte count (bcount) associated with a pointer (iptr)
    1196             : from a given data map.
    1197             : */
    1198             : #define get_mapped_byte_count(map, iptr, bcount)                             \
    1199             : {                                                                            \
    1200             :   uintptr_t         hash = hash_ptr(iptr);                                   \
    1201             :   a_map_index       mask = (map)->hash_mask;                                 \
    1202             :   a_map_index       idx = hash & mask;                                       \
    1203             :   a_data_map_entry  *table = (map)->table;                                   \
    1204             :   for (;;) {                                                                 \
    1205             :     a_byte  *tptr = table[idx].ptr;                                          \
    1206             :     if (tptr == (a_byte*)(iptr)) {                                           \
    1207             :       (bcount) = table[idx].data.byte_count;                                 \
    1208             :       break;                                                                 \
    1209             :     } else if (tptr == NULL) {                                               \
    1210             :       (bcount) = 0;                                                          \
    1211             :       break;                                                                 \
    1212             :     }  /* if */                                                              \
    1213             :     idx = (idx+1) & mask;                                                    \
    1214             :   }  /* for */                                                               \
    1215             : }
    1216             : 
    1217             : 
    1218             : /*
    1219             : Convenience macro to retrieve a pointer (sptr) to the stack storage associated
    1220             : with an IL pointer (iptr).  ips is the interpreter state managing the stack
    1221             : storage.
    1222             : */
    1223             : #define get_stack_bytes(ips, iptr, sptr)                                     \
    1224             :   get_mapped_ptr(&(ips)->map, iptr, sptr)
    1225             : 
    1226             : #if DEBUG
    1227             : 
    1228           0 : void db_data_map(void  *map_address)
    1229             : /*
    1230             : Output some information about a data map's contents
    1231             : */
    1232             : {
    1233           0 :   a_data_map        *map = (a_data_map*)map_address;
    1234           0 :   a_data_map_entry  *table = map->table;
    1235           0 :   a_map_index       mask = map->hash_mask;
    1236           0 :   a_map_index       k, n_slots = mask+1;
    1237             : 
    1238           0 :   for (k = 0; k<n_slots; ++k) {
    1239           0 :     a_byte  *ptr = table[k].ptr;
    1240           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "[%2u] ", k);
    1241           0 :     if (ptr == NULL) {
    1242           0 :       fprintf(f_debug, "(empty)\n");
    1243             :     } else {
    1244           0 :       fprintf(f_debug, "h = %2u  %p\n",
